hero.title: Sleep Calculator
hero.description: Use our sleep cycle calculator to find your ideal bedtime and wake-up time. Discover recommended sleep by age, optimize your sleep schedule, and wake up feeling refreshed with the perfect sleep duration for every age group.
hero.fallAsleepTime: The average human takes 15 minutes to fall asleep.

hero.wakeupResult: If you go to sleep right now, you should try to wake up at one of the following times:

features.title: Sleep Cycle Calculator: How It Works
features.subtitle: A sleep cycle calculator is a simple formula that helps you plan how much sleep you need to feel refreshed. All you need is your desired wake-up time. Here's how it works:
features.cycle90Minutes: The average sleep cycle lasts about 90 minutes.
features.fiveCycles: A typical night includes 5 full sleep cycles, which equals 7.5 hours of sleep (90 × 5 = 450 minutes).
features.countBack: To find your ideal bedtime, start from your wake-up time and count back 7.5 hours.
features.example: Example: If you need to wake up at 6:00 AM, your ideal bedtime would be around 10:30 PM. This is when you should be in bed, ready to sleep.
features.adjustment: This calculation is a starting point because everyone's sleep cycles can vary slightly. Try this bedtime for a week and adjust as needed:
features.tooEarly: If you wake up too early (more than 5–10 minutes before your alarm), move your bedtime slightly later.
features.sleepThrough: If you still sleep through your alarm after a week, shift your bedtime earlier.
features.increments: Make adjustments in 15-minute increments until you wake naturally just before your alarm.
features.optimization: By following this method, you can optimize your sleep, wake up feeling refreshed, and make the most of your night's rest.

useCases.title: Recommended Sleep by Age – Sleep Cycle Calculator Insights
useCases.subtitle: The amount of sleep you need varies depending on several factors, including age, genetics, lifestyle, and daily activity levels. Using a sleep cycle calculator can help you plan your bedtime and wake-up times according to your personal sleep needs.
useCases.authoritiesNote: Health authorities, such as the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM), provide general sleep guidelines for all age groups based on scientific research and expert knowledge.
useCases.howToUseTitle: How to Use This With a Sleep Cycle Calculator:
useCases.step1: Combine your age-specific sleep requirements with a sleep cycle calculator to find your ideal bedtime and wake-up time.
useCases.step2: Adults should aim for at least 7 hours of sleep, ideally completing full 90-minute sleep cycles.
useCases.step3: Children and teens need more sleep to support growth, learning, and optimal health, so plan bedtimes accordingly.
useCases.tracking: Tracking your sleep using this method can help you wake up feeling refreshed and energized, while ensuring sufficient sleep duration by age.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.description: Find answers to common questions about using our sleep calculator for various purposes.
faq.question1: What time should I wake up?
faq.answer1: You should aim to wake up at the end of a 90-minute sleep cycle. Use our calculator to find the best wake-up times so you feel refreshed instead of groggy.
faq.question2: What time should I go to bed?
faq.answer2: Your bedtime depends on when you plan to wake up. Enter your wake-up time in the calculator, and it will suggest several bedtimes based on natural sleep cycles.
faq.question3: How much sleep do I need calculator?
faq.answer3: Most adults need 7–9 hours of sleep. Our calculator helps you plan around sleep cycles, not just hours, so you wake up at the right stage of sleep.
faq.question4: If I go to sleep at 10 AM what time will I wake up?
faq.answer4: If you go to sleep at 10 AM, the calculator can show you the best wake-up times based on full cycles. For example, 11:45 AM, 1:15 PM, 2:45 PM, and so on.
faq.question5: What time to sleep to wake up at 6?
faq.answer5: To wake up at 6 AM, ideal bedtimes are around 8:45 PM, 10:15 PM, or 11:45 PM the night before. These times align with complete sleep cycles.
